item.title: 5 years ago they protested for freedom in Hong Kong. They want us to remember them
item.description: Five years after mass protests disrupted Hong Kong, and were crushed by the government, people who took part are downsizing their dreams and ambitions — but keeping a small flame of hope alive.

item.title: Ukrainian parliamentarian wants a statue of Ronald Reagan in Kiev square
item.description: A petition is circulating in Ukraine to erect a statue of late U.S. President Ronald Reagan in the capital Kyiv. This is the second time Parliamentarian Maryan Zablot-shkyy has launched such a drive.

item.title: The Republican Party lays out its 2024 policy platform
item.description: The RNC's Platform Committee has adopted former President Donald Trump’s platform, a document that leans into his preferred “America First” stances and steers away from traditional GOP social issues.

item.title: Families of place crash victims react to Boeing's plea agreement
item.description: Families of victims of two Boeing 747 Max crashes are asking a judge to reject a plea deal with the plane maker. NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks talks to attorney Paul Cassell, who represents 15 of the families.

item.title: How to fight shrinkflation? Pay attention to unit prices at grocery stores
item.description: Companies have waged a quiet revolution in package sizing that they use to squeeze more money out of us. But there’s a weapon to help consumers level the playing field: unit prices.

item.title: Why judicial appointments by the next president are important to climate change law
item.description: Due to the litigious nature of environmental and climate law, legal experts say the next president's judicial appointments might be their most consequential actions on climate over the next five years.

item.title: Far from the ocean, remnants of storms like Beryl can cause severe floods
item.description: Even after storms lose their hurricane status and head far inland, they can still cause dangerous floods. Storms like Beryl pose risks far from the coast, even in Canada.

item.title: Louisiana plantation where historic slave revolt started now under Black ownership
item.description: The Louisiana plantation home where one of the largest slave revolts in U.S. history began has Black owners for the first time. They say the 1811 uprising can inspire a new generation to fight racism.

item.title: Colorado is the 2nd state to approve licenses for outdoor preschools
item.description: A new law opens up outdoor preschools to low income families in Colorado by allowing them to accept state child care subsidies. Advocates say learning outdoors has advantages over indoor classrooms.
